title: Why does Instagram delete my videos with copyrighted music all of a sudden? - Quora

response.answer_text: Because rightsholders are taking notice. YouTube was the biggest platform for sharing videos, but Facebook actually beats it by a fairly narrow margin. Unfortunately for rightsholders, they have far less quality control because they’re a social platform first and a video sharing site second. They don’t have YouTube’s almighty algorithm and bots and whatnot to scour the billions of bytes on a near-instantaneous basis. Say what you will about false copyright claims & unwarranted account strikes, at least there is a system to fix in case things go sour. Facebook is a dinosaur by comparison, and Instagram is one of its eggs. They don’t have the mechanism in place to meet rightsholders halfway, like when YouTube used to mute your video or divert ad revenue or (sometimes/once upon a time) allow the video to remain up but with a link to buy the song through Amazon or iTunes added to the description. It’s no skin off Facetagram’s nose if a record company comes-a-knockin’ for them to just flush the stash down the toilet and say, “What infringement?”. There’s less red tape for everyone involved, and the only people getting the short end of the stick are nobodies looking for their 15 minutes in the sun by taking the easy way (no offense, I’m sure you work hard on your videos; you could probably just stand to give it an extra 10%). You have options: simplest, maybe not easiest: make your own music. Learn an instrument, be it a piano or a theremin or a drumpad app on your iPad. Take those singing lessons you’ve always secretly wanted to. Get some friends to help you out; everyone knows someone who’s in a band.simplest, somewhat easier: invest in some royalty-free tracks. YouTube has an entire audio library of downloadable tracks you can use just about anywhere (not exclusively YouTube, though check each track’s individual license terms). There’s whole sets of free-to-use discs out there that may seem costly upfront, but bear in mind you can use the tracks any which way you want. It’s as valid an expense as anything else you’d use to produce a video.simplest & easiest: don’t have music in your videos, hit that mute button before you upload. If your video is interesting enough, it won’t need the sound.

You are asking a lot of questions here. The one that really seems to be the core of your concern is “Why is Instagram inconsistent in applying their copyright controls to infringing videos?” The answer to that will never be satisfactory, because there are a ton of factors, some of which Instagram cannot control. You’ll just have to accept that they are inconsistent. But as for why they deleted all of your videos, I think you already know why. You were using music made by someone else and your videos were infringing on copyright. As for the timing, be aware that as new platforms add video, that makes for more work for the music publishers in tracking down use of their music and having it removed. You say “Instagram never used to do this…”, but sort of ignore that they eventually would as the music publishers find their songs on Instagram’s website. Instagram has no choice here, if they don’t remove the videos, they get sued by the music companies for millions. You cannot legally use someone else’s music. Come on, you already know that! I really don’t think you are complaining about “Hey, get this other guy too!” You are really complaining that you got caught and suffered a very small penalty.
